Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Isolation by Distance or Adaptation: The Extent of Population Genetic Distance that Results from Adaptive Divergence in Intraspecific Signals and Migratory Behavior
Award.AbstractNarration:
Classic debates on the formation of new species center on the relative significance of geographic isolation and adaption to different environments. New tools in genomics allow a closer look into how these features influence population differentiation. By analyzing how patterns of genomic variation among populations are affected by local ecology, behavior and extent of geographic isolation, important insights about how biodiversity forms can be achieved. Barn swallows are comprised of six closely related sub-species worldwide, where populations vary in: (1) geographic distance from one another, (2) different combinations of mate-selection traits, (3) climates they encounter, and (4) their extent of migratory behaviors, and thus provide powerful opportunities to explore the relative significance of these factors in population divergence. Fifty-five sampling sites across the entire breeding distribution of barn swallows have been established to conduct nearly 1,500 pair-wise population comparisons of genomic and phenotypic divergence.

This investigation will be among the most comprehensive analyses of the relative significance of migratory behavior, climate variability, mate selection, and geographic distance on population genomic divergence, with important insights about how these factors affect the evolution of new species. Here, the scientific goals can be achieved through intermeshing the research with international collaboration, integrative training in Biology and outreach. Two Science Education Fellows will be used to help implement and assess innovation to two courses taught by the PI. Public engagement in this research will be achieved via a newly established Citizen Science program and an exhibition on avian diversity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Classic debates in evolutionary ecology have centered on the roles of divergent natural selection (Isolation by Adaptation, or IBA) and geographic distance (Isolation by Distance, or IBD) in restricting gene flow and contributing to speciation. To analyze the relative importance of these hypotheses we conducted extensive sampling across the entire breeding distribution of the barn swallow Hirundo rustica species complex. Barn swallows comprise six sub-species worldwide which vary in: 1) geographic range, 2) degree of genomic divergence, 3) signaling traits and 4) migratory behavior.

Our broad geographic sampling enabled us to test the relative significance of IBA (via trait divergence, variation in climate, and variation in migratory behavior) and IBD on patterns of genomic divergence in the barn swallow species complex. During this grant period, we conducted extensive geographic sampling of all six subspecies of barn swallows, including the discovery of hybrid zones in Russia, China, and Mongolia. For the thousands of individuals sampled, we collected genomic, phenotypic, and isotopic data. Analysis of stable isotopes and the deployment of geolocator tags demonstrates the presence of migratory divides near hybrid zones. Results indicate that morphological traits underlain by selection contribute to genomic differences among populations in allopatry and to the maintenance of isolation in secondary contact.  Specifically, differences in ventral color and migratory phenotype explain a significant amount of genome-wide divergence among closely related, yet geographically isolated populations, even when controlling for the geographic distances among populations. Moreover, the same traits that predict genome-wide divergence in allopatry are associated with the extent of hybridization when populations come into contact.

Using high throughput genomic data and demographic modeling has enabled us to place the barn swallow species complex in a broader context in terms of its range expansion, which appears to coincide and track the movement and construction of human settlements out of Africa and into the northern hemisphere. Thus, the expansion of barn swallows into the northern hemisphere and phenotype divergence has occurred quite rapidly.

The Broader Impacts associated with this project have included extensive training of students and international collaboration. Five honor?s thesis projects and middle school science curricula development were funded through REU and RET supplements. An active blog shares the research with a broad audience. Improvements to teaching through formal collaboration and assessment, and further development of an outreach program on science communication, were made. More than 25 manuscripts and associated data have been published with several more in progress. To date, the work has been disseminated through 39 departmental seminars, and several invited conference talks, including four symposia and four plenary/keynote talks.
